channel.title: Health - Digg
channel.description: Health on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: This Live Map Shows The Prevalence Of COVID-19 Symptoms In Every County
item.description: Facebook and the Carnegie Mellon University Delphi Research Center have teamed up to track the prevalence of COVID-19 and flu symptoms around the country.

item.title: How Should Airlines Change Post-Pandemic?
item.description: Let's think big: how would you create the ideal flying experience? What drives you crazy about flying and what do you never want to deal with again?

item.title: How Coronavirus Testing Fumbles Squandered Valuable Time
item.description: As coronavirus test kits were malfunctioning in public health labs across the country, Dr. Robert Redfield repeatedly assured his fellow task force officials in February that the problem would be quickly solved.

item.title: We Tested All Our Patients For Coronavirus. 88 Percent Of Those Infected Were Asymptomatic
item.description: The findings have huge implications for everyday life on a labor and delivery unit, as well as potential broader implications.

item.title: Cuomo Says It's Time To Start 'Reimagining' What Life Will Be In New York After COVID-19
item.description: As new cases and deaths continue to decline, the governor said he wants to use the opportunity to make New York a better place when it does re-open.

item.title: The Job Losses Caused By The Coronavirus Pandemic Compared To Other Historical Periods Of Job Loss, Visualized
item.description: Over the last four weeks, more than 22 million people have filed jobless claims filed because of COVID-19. Here's how that compares to the numbers of other historical job losses over the past few decades.

item.title: Social Distancing Diaries: Surviving A Virtual School Day
item.description: The physical and mental challenges of quarantine are daunting enough. Add two screaming kids and teaching kindergarten to the mix? Anarchy.

item.title: I Sampled My Way Through The Wild World Of High-End Cannabis Products
item.description: If luxury THC granola, weed aperitifs and CBD pillows couldn't make me into a stoner, nothing can.

item.title: New York Needed Ventilators. So They Developed One In A Month
item.description: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.

item.title: After Years On The Decline, Hepatitis C Is Returning — Primarily Among Millennials
item.description: Much to the surprise of public health officials, a once-declining disease is surging again and heavily impacting people who are under age 40.

item.title: A Billionaires' Compound With Its Own Coronavirus Testing Center Stokes Anger On The French Riviera
item.description: "The very rich," F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, "are different from you and me." Rarely has that statement been so glaringly clear, as the self-isolation strategies of the ultrawealthy are revealed by the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: It's Not Too Late To Go On Offense Against The Coronavirus
item.description: To end the nightmare, lockdowns aren't enough. We need to hunt the virus and defeat it.

item.title: Yes, Liquor Stores Are Essential Businesses
item.description: Keeping them open can help people with alcohol use disorder avoid withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, hallucinations and seizures

item.title: Here's How Our Immunity Responses To COVID-19 Compare With Other Diseases
item.description: From chicken pox to the common cold, here's where our immune response to COVID-19 might lie on the spectrum.

item.title: How Architects Can Stop COVID-19 From Spreading Indoors
item.description: Daylight, natural ventilation and unfinished wood surfaces can all reduce the abundance of harmful pathogens.

item.title: To Run My Best Marathon At Age 44, I Had To Outrun My Past
item.description: After 20 years of long-distance competition, I ran my fastest. All it took was tech, training and a new understanding of my life.

item.title: Feeling Guilty For Not Doing Enough? You Are
item.description: What you're feeling is totally normal. Here's how to avoid the spiral.

item.title: Coronavirus News Fatigue Is Real And It Could Become A Big Problem
item.description: The spike in views of coronavirus coverage is falling away — but it's vital that journalists hold the public's attention if we're going to keep the pandemic at bay.

item.title: 11 Numbers That Show How The Coronavirus Has Changed New York City
item.description: Unemployment has skyrocketed, but so has the size of the city's volunteer pool and the number of people fostering animals. One month into the shutdown, the city is as complex as it ever was.

item.title: A Mathematical Proposal For How To Exit From The COVID-19 Lockdown
item.description: One practical exit strategy from lockdown would be identifying green zones, and progressively joining them together once it is safe to do so.

item.title: The Coronavirus Revealed America's Failures
item.description: The coronavirus didn't break America. It revealed what was already broken.

item.title: 'We're Making Death Dollars': I Drive A Packed New York Bus 13 Hours A Day
item.description: "Nobody is regulating anything if the buses are super crowded. I'm regulating it myself."

item.title: I'm Stuck In Isolation With The Man Who's Divorcing Me
item.description: This is life in the time of coronavirus, where a 46-year-old woman from Indiana is stuck self-quarantining with her husband, one month after he asked for a divorce.

item.title: The White House Has Erected A Blockade Stopping States and Hospitals From Getting Coronavirus PPE
item.description: The New England Journal of Medicine has published a horrifying account of a health care executive going to extraordinary lengths to evade what appear to be mafia tactics by the federal government in order to obtain personal protective equipment.
item.kicker: THE STATES VS. THE UNITED STATES

item.title: The Problem With Heroizing Healthcare Workers Like Me
item.description: We don't want glory. We just want our jobs to be protected — in every sense.
item.kicker: GLORY ISN'T A CLEAN N95 MASK

item.title: How Does Coronavirus Kill? Clinicians Trace A Ferocious Rampage Through The Body, From Brain To Toes
item.description: As confirmed COVID-19 deaths surpass 150,000, clinicians and pathologists are struggling to understand the damage wrought by the coronavirus as it tears through the body.

item.title: Report: The US Will Need To Do 20 Million Tests A Day To Reopen Safely
item.description: A group of experts has produced a plan for the US to reopen its economy safely this summer. However, it's contingent on doing at least 20 million tests every day, scaling up contact tracing, and ensuring those who need to isolate can be properly supported.

item.title: What We Can Learn From The 'Second Wave' Of Coronavirus Cases In Asia
item.description: Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan show the challenges of fighting this pandemic.
item.kicker: KEEP YOUR TEST ON A SWIVEL

item.title: 70 Died At A Nursing Home As Body Bags Piled Up. This Is What Went Wrong
item.description: The sprawling New Jersey nursing home, which was chronically short of staff and protective equipment, quickly fell prey to the coronavirus.

item.title: Watch This Stand-Off In Denver Between A Protester And Healthcare Worker
item.description: To protest the stay-at-home-orders, drivers attempted to clog certain roads in Denver, Colorado, on Sunday.

item.title: Protesting For The Right To Catch The Coronavirus
item.description: The reopen America protests are the logical conclusion of a twisted liberty movement.

item.title: This Harvard Epidemiologist Is Very Popular On Twitter. But Does He Know What He's Talking About?
item.description: Eric Feigl-Ding has been making the rounds on TV as a coronavirus expert. Some of his colleagues think he's unqualified.

item.title: Seoul's Full Cafes, Apple Store Lines Show Mass Testing Success
item.description: Cafes bustled with customers, parks teemed with sunbathers, and the first Apple store to reopen outside China had lines snaking out the door as many South Koreans — almost all wearing masks — emerged from months of self-isolation.

item.title: A Beloved Bar Owner Was Skeptical About The Virus. Then He Took A Cruise
item.description: Joe Joyce oversaw JJ Bubbles, a welcoming tavern in a conservative corner of Brooklyn, for 43 years until he died of Covid-19.

item.title: 'Nothing To Worry About' And 'It's Being Contained': How Trump Officials Downplayed The Coronavirus
item.description: A timeline of how Trump officials, like new White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany, downplayed the coronavirus well into March.

item.title: The Scarlet C: Coronavirus Survivors Face The Stigma And Discrimination
item.description: Even after they recover, coronavirus survivors face the stigma of the disease.

item.title: The Coronavirus In America: The Year Ahead
item.description: More than 20 experts in public health, medicine and history shared their thoughts on the future. Most believed that once the crisis was over, the nation and its economy would revive quickly. But there would be no escaping a period of intense pain.
item.kicker: 'IF WE UNDERESTIMATE THE VIRUS, IT WILL FIND US'

item.title: Florida Sees Most New Coronavirus Cases Reported After Three-Day Drop In Numbers
item.description: Florida had 1,413 new reported cases of COVID-19 Friday, the highest number of new cases since the outbreak began more than a month ago, according to the state's Department of Health. It also reported 58 new deaths since Thursday evening.
item.kicker: AND NOW THEY'RE OPENING THE BEACHES

item.title: Contamination At CDC Lab Delayed Rollout Of Coronavirus Tests
item.description: The failure by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to quickly produce a test kit for detecting the novel coronavirus was triggered by a glaring scientific breakdown at the CDC's central laboratory complex in Atlanta, according to scientists with knowledge of the matter and a determination by federal regulators.
item.kicker: 'THEY DIDN'T HAVE A TEST THAT WORKED'

item.title: Coronavirus Testing Needs To Triple Before The United States Can Reopen, Experts Say
item.description: As some governors consider easing social distancing restrictions, new estimates by researchers at Harvard University suggest that the United States cannot safely reopen unless it conducts more than three times the number of coronavirus tests it is currently administering over the next month.
item.kicker: A MINIMUM OF 152 TESTS PER 100K PEOPLE

item.title: Which Mask Should You Wear?
item.description: Here's a look at some of the types of masks you might encounter, how they work, what to consider when making your own and the level of protection they could provide.

item.title: Coronavirus Is Reducing CO2. Why That's Worrisome
item.description: A growing number of estimates say global carbon dioxide emissions could fall 5% in 2020. That would be the largest annual drop on record. But climate researchers say there is little reason for celebration.
item.kicker: CAN WE PLEASE CATCH A BREAK? ANYWHERE?

item.title: What It's Like Working At A Grocery Store During COVID-19
item.description: One cashier provides an honest look at daily life providing this essential service to the American public.

item.title: Inside The Global Social Media Movement That Claims It Changed The CDC's Mind On Masks
item.description: It's increasingly advised that to stop the spread of coronavirus, everyone should wear a mask. Online groups, fueled by a viral image, are taking credit.

item.title: We're All Living In 'The Lighthouse'
item.description: Signs that life in isolation is like Robert Eggers's 2019 horror movie "The Lighthouse," now streaming on Amazon Prime.
item.kicker: THEY GAVE US ALL THE CLUES

item.title: The Occupations With The Highest Risk Of Coronavirus Exposure, Visualized
item.description: According to this chart from Visual Capitalist, some US workers are more susceptible to putting themselves in harm's way.

item.title: We Are Probably Only One-Tenth Of The Way Through This Pandemic
item.description: Getting out of the lockdown and out of your shelter-in-place bunker is not the beginning of the end of the pandemic. It is only the end of the beginning.

item.title: A Vital Hack Could Turn Medical Devices Into Ventilators
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of lower-grade breathing devices are going unused because manufacturers say they can't perform life-saving functions. But a new patch might change that.
item.kicker: HACK THE PLANET, SAVE THE WORLD

item.title: How South Korea Held National Elections During The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: South Korea's elections this week offer lessons on how to safely conduct an election amid the COVID-19 outbreak.
item.kicker: LOTS OF SANITIZER, MASKS AND GLOVES

item.title: Black Miami Doctor Handcuffed While Helping Homeless During Pandemic
item.description: "Situations like this have escalated into black men being shot all across the country," Dr. Armen Henderson said.
